title: NEW_README Meta-Documentation Template
description: Documents the prompts, principles, and source files used to generate each section of NEW_README.md from first principles
approach: Problem-solution narrative with progressive disclosure and modern README best practices
designPrinciples: Lead with the problem, not features
Show, don't tell (visual diagrams, concrete examples)
Progressive disclosure (Quick Start â†’ Deep Dive)
Actionable content (every section has 'what to do')
User perspective (written for the person using it)

sections.prompt: Create a compelling title and tagline that: (1) States what this is ('Convergent Development'), (2) Promises transformation ('endless exploration â†’ shipped software'), (3) Hints at target audience ('divergent thinking'), (4) Add badges for version, Python requirement, and license to establish credibility.
sourceFiles: pyproject.toml - Extract version (2.0.0), Python requirement (3.11+), license (MIT)
pyproject.toml - Extract repository URL for badge links
sections.regenerationNotes: Update version from pyproject.toml. Keep tagline focused on user transformation, not technical features.

sections.prompt: Articulate the core problem this solves from the user's perspective. Start with empathy ('You're a divergent thinker'), describe the pain (100 ideas but need to ship 3), pose 4 critical questions the reader is asking themselves, end with the false dichotomy most methodologies present (creative OR systematic).
sourceFiles: pyproject.toml - Note 'Transform divergent exploration into focused implementation' capability
designPrinciples: Empathy first (speak to the reader's experience)
sections.regenerationNotes: Don't list features here. Focus purely on the reader's pain and frustration. The problem section should resonate emotionally.

sections.prompt: Present the solution as a visual journey with emojis showing the complete flow. Keep it to one sentence of prose plus a visual diagram. End with the three key numbers: 4 workflows, 11 agents, 1 methodology.
sourceFiles: context/workflows/ - Count workflows (4: CONVERGENCE, SPRINT_PLANNING, TDD_CYCLE, ISSUE_CAPTURE)
sections.regenerationNotes: Update agent count if agents are added/removed. Keep the visual flow diagram simple and scannable.

sections.prompt: Provide 3-step installation with clear comments. (1) Install collection with full repository URL, (2) Install beads with explanation of why it's REQUIRED, (3) Verification commands. Use numbered comments in bash code block.
sections.regenerationNotes: Keep this section brief. Goal is 'running in 2 minutes'. Save explanations for later sections.

sections.sectionName: Quick Start - Your First Convergence Session

context/workflows/CONVERGENCE_PROCESS.md - The 4 phases (DIVERGE, CAPTURE, CONVERGE, DEFER)
agents/convergence-architect.md - How the agent guides the process

sections.regenerationNotes: Use a realistic, relatable example. 'Documentation tool' works because everyone has documentation. Avoid abstract examples.

sections.prompt: For each of the 4 workflows, create a subsection with: (1) H3 heading with emoji and transformation (X â†’ Y), (2) Command to run, (3) 'What happens' with numbered or bulleted steps, (4) Output section listing concrete files/artifacts, (5) Time estimate. sections.prompt: Create 4 categorized tables of agents with columns: Agent (bold name), Role (one-line description), When to Use (actionable guidance). Categories: Workflow Orchestrators (4), Implementation & Architecture (3), Tracking & Organization (2), Cleanup & Maintenance (2). Extract role from first paragraph of each agent file.

sections.prompt: Create a quick-reference table of all commands with columns: Command (no prefix), Purpose (one-line), Typical Use (when you'd run it). Include all commands from context/commands/ directory. Add note about prefix.

sections.regenerationNotes: Update if commands are added/removed. Keep purposes brief (one line each). Preserve the workflow sequence (0-4 + status).

sections.prompt: Walk through a complete 8-10 day journey building a realistic project. Structure as Day 1, Day 2, Days 3-5, etc. Show: (1) Actual commands run, (2) What happened (commented), (3) Concrete numbers (23 features explored, 3 converged, 20 deferred), (4) Actual outputs, (5) Total time. Use a relatable example project.
sourceFiles: context/workflows/CONVERGENCE_PROCESS.md - Typical convergence duration and outputs
sections.regenerationNotes: Use a project everyone can relate to (documentation, CLI tool, etc.). Show realistic timelines. Include both success and issues discovered.

sections.prompt: List the 4 core philosophical principles from foundation collection. Each gets: (1) H3 heading with number, (2) 3-5 bullet points explaining the principle with concrete practices. Principles: Ruthless Simplicity, Value-First Delivery, Test-Driven Development, Trust in Emergence.
sections.regenerationNotes: These principles should align with foundation collection. Don't add new principles without foundation alignment.

sections.prompt: Two subsections: (1) Software - list Python version, Amplifier, Foundation, Beads with version constraints from pyproject.toml, (2) Skills - list 3-4 soft requirements (command line, domain knowledge, willingness to defer).
sections.regenerationNotes: Update versions from pyproject.toml. Skills section can evolve based on user feedback.

sections.prompt: Organize tips by workflow phase with H3 headings: During Convergence, During Sprint Planning, During TDD, During Issue Tracking. Extract best practices from workflow documentation. Use bullet points. Make each tip actionable (imperative voice).

sections.prompt: Answer 5 common questions users might have. Format as H3 questions, prose answers. Questions: (1) What if I don't want beads?, (2) Can I skip TDD?, (3) What if backlog is huge?, (4) How to find deferred features?, (5) Non-software projects?. Keep answers honest and pragmatic.
sections.regenerationNotes: Update based on actual user questions. Add new FAQs as patterns emerge. Remove FAQs that no one asks.

sections.prompt: Include standard Microsoft open-source contributing section with NOTE about not currently accepting contributions. Include CLA link and Code of Conduct reference. Keep this section largely unchanged.

Standard Microsoft trademark disclaimer. Keep unchanged.
End with bold call to action: 'Ready to transform...' followed by the exact commands to get started. Make it copy-pasteable. This is the final push to action.

Echo the transformation promise from opening

regenerationInstructions.overview: To regenerate NEW_README.md from scratch, follow the problem-solution narrative structure with progressive disclosure.
steps: 1. Start with empathy and problem articulation (not features)
3. Get user to Quick Start as fast as possible (< 100 lines)
4. Progressively disclose: workflows â†’ agents â†’ deep dive
5. Use real-world example to make it tangible
6. Explain architecture only after showing value
7. End with FAQ, legal, and strong CTA
8. Throughout: show don't tell, use visuals, be actionable
structuralPrinciples: Hook (problem) â†’ Promise (solution) â†’ Quick Win (Quick Start) â†’ Deep Dive (How It Works) â†’ Proof (Example) â†’ Trust (Architecture, Philosophy) â†’ Action (CTA)
Every section should be self-contained but build on previous
Use consistent formatting within categories (workflows, agents, tips)
Progressive disclosure: essential info first, details later
Visual hierarchy: H2 for major sections, H3 for subsections, tables for reference
verificationChecks: Agent count matches: ls agents/*.md | wc -l = 11
Command count matches: ls context/commands/*.md | wc -l = 6
All commands are copy-pasteable and correct
All directory paths match actual structure
All agent names exist in agents/ directory

whenToUseThisREADME: You want to attract new users who don't know they need this
Your audience is divergent thinkers struggling with convergence
You prioritize quick wins over comprehensive reference
Your project's value comes from solving a felt problem
